title: PDF non anti-aliased
content:
hello,

how can I export a document from indesign, to pdf, using a pixel font, and make it looks not anti-aliased in pdf?
author: gontijo

comments.content: Doesn't the option to anti-alias fonts rest with the end-user of Acrobat/Adobe Reader not the originator of the pdf itself?
the problem is: if the person who will read the pdf doesn't know how to enable the option... he will see the font looking soft.
The biggest flaw of all pdfs: users!
... so, there is nothing I can do to FORCE the user, to see the pdf the way I want?

Are you sure you are using the term "antialiased", and the reverse, "make it looks not anti-aliased", correctly?  
"Aliased" is jaggy, with hard edges. "Antialiased" is with constructed soft edges.

Using a pixel font, the text will (nearly) always be aliased. The "nearly" qualifier is because Acrobat _also_ is able to antialias monochrome bitmaps of sufficiently high resolution (one can guess that to be \> 1.5 x physical screen dpi).

If you _have_ a real pixel (bitmap) font that you can use in InDesign, that will be passed on to the PDF unchanged; i.e., as pixels.

However, I'm pretty sure you cannot use real bitmap fonts in InDesign--it's way too smart to allow that. Perhaps you have a simulated pixel font instead ( [Press Start](http://web.archive.org/web/20111211234414/http:/www.zone38.net/font/) comes first to mind). Those fonts are vector fonts, just like anything else, and just like other vector fonts it will be antialiased for screen in Acrobat.

If you really _really_ want a pixel font, create the text as image in Photoshop and place that into InDesign.

Alternatively, you can do it the other way around: read your InDesign created PDF into Photoshop and rasterize; then save that as PDF again.

I'm using unibody 8 ( [http://www.underware.nl/site2/index.php?id1=unibody&id2=overview](http://web.archive.org/web/20111211234414/http:/www.underware.nl/site2/index.php?id1=unibody&id2=overview "http://www.underware.nl/site2/index.php?id1=unibody&id2=overview") ).

Well, you got the idea...  
=D  
the font needs to look aliased, with hard edges.

The photoshop solution looks like a good one.

thanks guys.

Unibody is just a vector font, so it should look pretty much the same in the PDF as at did in InDesign. However they might be anti-aliased for screen in both Acrobat and InDesign.

Placing an image would probably be the best idea indeed.
Won't the images still be smoothed by user preference? Smooth images is a check box right next to smooth text.
I think image smoothing kicks in only with high-res pixel images. In any size large enough to read, the 'pixels' of vectorized bitmap fonts are \*huge\*.
